fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Some customer workflows rely on knowing the last successfully deployed version. This currently requires manual scripting to find.
h3. Suggested Solution
Add a new variable to return the last successfully deployed version
h3. Workaround
{code:sql}select VERSION_NAME 
from DEPLOYMENT_RESULT r 
join DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT e on (r.ENVIRONMENT_ID = e.ENVIRONMENT_ID)
where name = '<environment-name>' 
and deployment_state = 'Successful' 
order by started_date desc 
limit 1;{code}
fields.summary: Last Successful Deployment variable

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a branch is deleted from Bamboo, build status is retained on Bitbucket Server. When there is a failed build associated with a branch in Bitbucket Server, Pull requests are blocked because of the merge requirement of "a minimum of 1 successful build". 

h3. Suggested Solution
 Add a DELETE call to the Remote Events sent to Bitbucket Server, which will delete references to builds and/or branches which are deleted in Bamboo.

h3. Workaround
To allow the Pull Requests to merge, an admin will need to temporarily remove that restriction from Bitbucket Server.
Alternatively, the Bitbucket Server REST API could be used to [update the build status for commits|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/latest/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html].
fields.summary: Send Branch deletion to Bitbucket Server and update Build details

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If a build triggers a subprocess, such as a source code checkout, if the subprocess doesn't return a completion code, the parent build process will not terminate the subprocess. This causes a build not to fail.

h3. Suggested Solution
Fail the build and kill child processes.
Also add an error showing that the build had to be force-stopped.
fields.summary: Fail a build if subprocess fails

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If sockets are not available on Windows agents, source code checkouts will fail with a Windows socket error

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a Windows agent with invalid WinSocks configuration that needs to be refreshed
# Set up a build with source code checkout
# Run the build

h3. Expected Results
The build runs as expected

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} file:
{noformat}
2017-07-20 17:29:26,299 WARN [sshd-SshServer[1272c81]-nio2-thread-1] [Nio2Acceptor] Caught IOException while accepting incoming connection from /127.0.0.1:53265: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket
java.io.IOException: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket{noformat}

h3. Workaround
To work around this error, please reset WinSocks as follows:
# Open the Command Prompt with elevated permissions (Run as Admin)
# Run the following command at the command prompt: {{netsh winsock reset}}
# Press Enter, and restart the computer

h3. Related
Improvement request: 
* [BAM-18569 - Improved reporting when git hangs on Windows agents due to socket error|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-18569]
fields.summary: Socket failure on Windows agents

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

On Windows agents, Git checkout can fail due to a socket error. The error, coming from Windows, is
{noformat}java.io.IOException: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
This error is not very user friendly, so Bamboo could add to or override the error.
For example: {noformat}Sockets unavailable, please reset WinSocks by running netsh winsock reset from the command prompt{noformat}

h3. Workaround
To work around this error, please reset WinSocks as follows:
# Open the Command Prompt with elevated permissions (Run as Admin)
# Run the following command at the command prompt: {{netsh winsock reset}}
# Press Enter, and restart the computer
fields.summary: Improved reporting when git hangs on Windows agents due to socket error

For each job, the "Tests" tab becomes visible as soon as the job is done. In other words all test results becomes visible as soon as all tests in a job is done.

For example, multiple parse tasks are allowed in a job. Wouldn't it be possible to update the results shown in the "Tests" tab after each parse task?

fields.description:
Create a custom task for JIRA that can intelligently find all unit test projects within the SLN, run them, and parse them.

A unit test project has a specific projectType in the csproj, it could use this.  It could also find any projects that contain the string "unittest"

*Use Case:*

Bamboo currently supports MS Test.  It has two tasks: MS TEST Runner and MS TEST Parser.   These two tasks must be run for each unit test project.

My build project has 20+ projects, and each has a unit test project.  It is unreasonable to have 40 tasks in the build plan just for running unit tests.
fields.summary: Ability for Bamboo to run multiple unit tests in one task - JIRA

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Plans created (or updated) by Specs fail to share artifact.

h3. Environment
- Tested in Linux
- Oracle Java 1.8.0_111

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan with a shared artifact through Bamboo UI.
# Create a deployment project, using the previous plan and previous shared artifact.
# Export the plan to Specs. Example code used:
{noformat}
Plan rootObject = new Plan(new Project()
        .key(new BambooKey("B68"))
        .name("BSP33668"),
        "PLAN1",
        new BambooKey("PL1"))
        .stages(new Stage("Stage1")
            .jobs(new Job("JOB1",
                new BambooKey("JOB1"))
                .artifacts(new Artifact()
                    .name("Artifact1")
                    .copyPattern("*"))
                .tasks(new VcsCheckoutTask()
                    .description("Checkout Default Repository")
                    .checkoutItems(new CheckoutItem().defaultRepository())
                    .cleanCheckout(true),
              	  new MavenTask()
                    .enabled(false)
                    .goal("clean test")
                    .jdk("JDK 1.8")
                    .executableLabel("Maven 3")
                    .hasTests(true)
                )
            )
        )
        .linkedRepositories("repo-consumer");

        bambooServer.publish(rootObject);
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
No changes at all.

h3. Actual Results
- Artifact is not shared anymore.
- Deployment project fails (see screenshot attached).
 
h3. Notes
No errors recorded in logs.

h3.Workaround
Manually sharing the artifact again.
fields.summary: Plans created (or updated) by Specs fail to share artifact.

fields.description:
h2. Summary
When Bamboo kills git command it leaves ssh process untouched. It will remain executed until JVM shutdown

h2. Details
Create plan with large repository checkout task. Use SSH key for repository authentication and native git as capability. Set command timeout for 1 minute in repository settings
Start build
See process list
{noformat}
ps axvf

java
  \-git
      \-ssh -o ...
{noformat}

Wait for 1 minute when checkout is timed out and Bamboo interrupts plan
See process list
{noformat}
ps axvf

java
  \-ssh -o ...
{noformat}

h2. Workaround
Manually kill ssh processes which are not children of git process
fields.summary: ssh process is not killed on git command timeout

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The contents of symlinks are getting removed by the clean working directory feature in Windows. This only affects Junctions. Windows also has a type of symlink just for directories, called Junctions (see *Notes* for more information). This does not affect soft links.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo 6.x building on Windows agents. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a test folder named *TestDirectory* inside the Windows server where the agent is running on.
# (!) Create a couple text files in there that can be safely removed as part of the test. Do not place important files inside this directory because they will get removed.
# Set up a *Script* task inside your build plan with the following command:
#* {code}
mklink /J "TestDirectory" "C:\Path\To\TestDirectory"
{code}
# During the build process Bamboo will create a symlink (Junction) to the *TestDirectory* inside the build working directory.
# Inside the *Job* configuration page, go to the {{Miscellaneous}} tab.
# Check the *Clean working directory after each build* box.
# Run a new build.

h3. Expected Results
The build working directory is clean after the build is finished. No errors. The symlink was successfully removed and the original directory exists with all its content.

h3. Actual Results
The build working directory is clean after the build is finished. No errors. The symlink was successfully removed and the original directory exists *BUT* all the data inside the original directory is now gone.
 
h3. Notes

(i) Junctions look and act like soft links. The key difference is that they allow you to link directories that are located on different local volumes (but still on the same computer). 

h3.Workaround
Do not use the *Clean working directory after each build* feature if you're using Junctions, instead add a new task at the end of your job and manually cleanup the build working directory using a *Script* task.
fields.summary: Contents of symlinks (Junctions) are getting removed by the clean working directory feature in Windows

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo specs usage lifecycle is detached from build lyfecycle - this makes it hard to implement pure CasC / PaC scenario when source code provides script / code to build itself.

It would be great to provide plan script (i.e. spec) just as we do with build tool spec (pom, gradle, ...). This, for example, allows you to refactor plans (adding / removing stages / jobs) without need to refactor / adopt older branches.

I propose the following use case:
 # Add files to VCS repository
 ** Java-based Bamboo specs
 ** pom.xml with 'generate-build-plan' profile
 ** Main project files, build scripts, ...
 # Add plan in Bamboo of new 'On-the-fly' type - this plan type has specific settings list:
 ** Project / Plan key and name
 ** Bootstrap repository (type, url, credentials, ...)
 ** Trigger(s)
 ** Plan generation strategy (in our case Maven run with specific profile)
 ** Branches settings
 ** Variables
 # When triggered plan does the following:
 ** Runs special 'bootstrap' stage / job:
 *** Makes check-out from bootstrap repository
 *** Runs strategy to generate plan being executed on-the-fly
 ** Continues build with generated plan

Here Bamboo spec doesn't have to know Bamboo URL / credentials, as well as generate project / plan coordinates - instead Bamboo takes plan generation strategy result and updates current plan with it.

AFAIU this approach will also require some special processing for 'On-the-fly' branches, as configuration will be unique for each branch. But it would be _very-very_ useful to at least have single buildNumber generation for all branches.
fields.summary: Generate plan configuration on-the-fly from VCS Bamboo Specs

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make sure you have a build plan correctly configured (e.g. SUP-AT)
# Run the following REST API for this plan:
{code:none|borderStyle=hidden|bgColor=transparent|fgColor=gray}$ curl -X POST --user admin -p -d "os_authType=basic&executeAllStages=true" -H "Content-Type:application/json" <Bamboo_URL>/rest/api/latest/queue/SUP-AT{code}

h3. Expected Results
We receive an answer similar to:
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?><restQueuedBuild planKey="SUP-AT" buildNumber="14" buildResultKey="SUP-AT-14"><triggerReason>Manual build</triggerReason><link href="<Bamboo_URL>/rest/api/latest/result/SUP-AT-14" rel="self"/></restQueuedBuild>
{code}

h3. Actual Results
We get a 500 error:
{noformat}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?><status><status-code>500</status-code><message>Unexpected character ('o' (code 111)): expected a valid value (number, String, array, object, 'true', 'false' or 'null')
 at [Source: org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteInputStream@72bc5fe0; line: 1, column: 2]</message><stack-trace>org.codehaus.jackson.JsonParseException: Unexpected character ('o' (code 111)): expected a valid value (number, String, array, object, 'true', 'false' or 'null')
 at [Source: org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteInputStream@72bc5fe0; line: 1, column: 2]
    at org.codehaus.jackson.JsonParser._constructError(JsonParser.java:1432)
    at org.codehaus.jackson.impl.JsonParserMinimalBase._reportError(JsonParserMinimalBase.java:385)

fields.description:
h3. Summary
It would be nice to have the ability to change the heap size of the elastic agents running on Windows images. 

h3. Environment
An _elastic agent_ is an agent that runs in the [Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2)|http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/]. An elastic agent process runs in an [elastic instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/elastic+instance] of an [elastic image|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/elastic+image].
 
h3. Notes
It is currently not possible to adjust the amount of memory allocated to the elastic agents from within the Bamboo GUI. For elastic agents running on Unix-based images there's a workaround available [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/OutOfMemory+Errors+in+Bamboo+elastic+agent]. However, the workaround described in that page does not work for elastic agents running on Windows.
fields.summary: Ability to adjust heap size of elastic agents running on Windows

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
There is no label showing the total of tests passed in the following Bamboo pages:
# *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*
# *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/test*
# *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD*

But we can see this information in the *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD/test page. This behavior is not consistent. At least a label with the total test could be shown in the above-cited pages. This will help the users to understand the relationship between the total tests and the breakdown information from each new failures, Existing failures, fixed and quarantine.

h3. Suggested Solution
* Show a label with the total passed tests in green at *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*
* Show a label show a label with the total tests in *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/tests*, similar to the ones seen in *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD/test*
* Show a summary of tests in *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD* similar to the one we see in the main plan summary (*<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*)

 
h3. Workaround
* Pik the number of total tests and subtract if from (New failures + Existing Failures + Quarantine/Skipped)
* *OR* go to the job tests page (*<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/test*) on each job to check this information 

h3. Reference of screens
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*
 !DOC-T1M-76.png|thumbnail! 
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/test*
 !DOC-T1M-76_tests.png|thumbnail! 
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD*
 !DOC-T1M-JOB1-76.png|thumbnail! 
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD/test*
 !DOC-T1M-JOB1-76_test.png|thumbnail!

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When the Bitbucket Server URL changes, users need to delete and recreate the Application link. However, there is no notification of this requirement.

h3. Suggested Solution
If Bamboo cannot access Bitbucket Server, add a notification to check the Application link URL. 
h3. Workaround
Please delete and recreate the Application link and re-save the Repository:
# Go to {{Bamboo Administration >> Overview >> Application links}}
# Delete the Bitbucket Server application link from Bamboo
# Go to {{Bitbucket Administration >> Application links}}
# Delete the Bamboo Application link from Bitbucket Server
# Recreate the Application link – this can be started from either application and you will be redirected to the other
# Re-save the Repository
(i) If the Repository is still unable to connect, you may need to delete and recreate the Repository

Note from linked ticket BAM-18273:
{panel:borderColor=blue|borderWidth=2}
If you have Plan Branches, these will need to be manually updated in the Bamboo database. To do this, please:
 # Stop Bamboo
 # Back up your Bamboo database for restore/recovery purposes
 # Run the following update query, replacing {{<old-url>}} and {{<new-url>}} as needed:
{code:sql}
update VCS_LOCATION as V
   set xml_definition_data = replace(xml_definition_data,'<old-url>','<new-url>');
{code}
 # Start Bamboo
{panel}

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After a plan that produces a Shared Artifact is deleted, any plan that consumes that artifact fails. Although this is expected, disabling the Artifact Download task should allow the plan to run.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Plan *Throwaway Artifact* that produces a Shared Artifact
# Create a second Plan *Artifact Test* that consumes the Shared Artifact
# Run the *Throwaway Artifact* Plan to produce the artifact
# Run *Artifact Test* to successfully consume the Artifact
# Disable the *Artifact Download task* in *Artifact Test*
# Delete the *Throwaway Artifact* Plan
# Re-run the *Artifact Test* Plan

h3. Expected Results
Because the Artifact Download task is disabled, it should not affect the execution of the build plan.

h3. Actual Results
The build does not start and the following exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} file and Build Result Summary page:

fields.description:
In order for Bamboo Specs to be used in an enterprise environment, it is critical to be able to determine when a plan configuration has been updated via Specs.  Currently there is no audit event generated to show this occurs.  This is a potential security risk.

Since audit log events do not appear to be generated for the addition of stages/tasks, this opens up a possibility where a bad actor can add and push malicious tasks via Specs and not leave any trail of the activity in the Bamboo plan audit log.
fields.summary: Audit log events for Bamboo Specs publishing

fields.description:
In BAM-18351, a flag to toggle branch cleanup for a particular branch was suggested as a new /plan/.../branch endpoint.  This would allow admins to programmatically toggle the cleanup status of plan branches.  However, it would also be beneficial to be able to fine-tune the plan branch deletion policy at creation time rather than have to go back after creation and push an API call.

In our use case, we have procedures that roll through a set of repositories and generate release branches.  This works well; however, because we cannot fine-tune branch expiration based on a regular expression, we need to go into each of _n_ release branches and manually uncheck the cleanup checkbox.  We not only have to do this for releases but for certain long-running (but potentially idle) branches, which should remain in place until merged.

The ideal UI change would would allow for a regular expression to control expiration.  The current UI looks like:
 * Delete plan branch
 ** (/) After branch was deleted from repository
 *** # days
 ** (/) After branch inactivity in repository
 *** # days

 

A more granular solution would look more like:
 * Delete plan branch
 ** (/) *Only delete plan branches matching the expression:*
 *** *(regex box)*
 ** (/) After branch was deleted from repository
 *** # days
 ** (/) After branch inactivity in repository
 *** # days
fields.summary: Allow regular expression control of plan branch deletion.

fields.description:
In -BAM-17224-, a flag to toggle branch cleanup for a particular branch was added to the /plan/.../branch endpoint.  This helps out quite a bit with the creation of branches, but a more practical use case is managing the cleanup status of branches which have already been detected and created, e.g. release branches.

In our use case, we have procedures that roll through a set of repositories and generate release branches.  This works well; however, because we cannot fine-tune branch expiration based on a regular expression, we need to go into each of _n_ release branches and manually uncheck the cleanup checkbox.  We not only have to do this for releases but for certain long-running (but potentially idle) branches, which should remain in place until merged.

 

There is already a /plan/<key>/enable endpoint, so it seems like a /plan/<key>enableCleanup endpoint would be simple and useful to implement as well.
fields.summary: Create REST endpoint to toggle branch cleanup option

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the below message is logged when Bamboo can't place a spot instance request due to [spot instance limits|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-spot-limits.html#spot-limits-general]:
{code}
2017-06-16 09:34:44,066 WARN [elastic-pool-4-thread-2] [AwsSpotInstanceLauncher] Unable to place a spot instance request, proceeding with regular instance order
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution
Log a reference to the reason the spot instance request couldn't be placed and had to fallback to a regular instance order. E.g. Include the AWS failure reason "Max spot instance count exceeded"
fields.summary: Improve the warning logged when a spot instance request can't be placed due to spot instance limits in Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If a Trigger is enabled, Change Detection runs after a build and tries to trigger a new build with any changes (BAM-18497). With customized builds ({{Run >> Run Customized}}), users have the option to run off of custom commit hashes, which may be on different branches. In these cases, Bamboo will not be able to download the changes and run the build. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a branch {{more_tests}} to a build
# Configure a variable for the branch name ({{BRANCH_NAME}})
# Add a trigger on the repository
# Do not merge {{more_tests}} to master
# Run a custom build using the {{more_tests}} branch

h3. Expected Results
Build runs as expected

h3. Actual Results
* A build ran as expected using the latest changeset on {{more_tests}}; but
* Immediately after the build, change detection finds the delta between the revision used in the custom build and the latest revision on the master branch and triggers a new build

The following appears in the Commits tab:
{noformat}[unknown]
Bamboo was unable to extract changes between revision <more_tests_commit_hash> and <master_commit_hash>.{noformat}
 
h3.Workaround
Remove any Triggers from the build
fields.summary: Do not run Change Detection after customized run

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Artifacts sharing does not work with using S3 and Remote handler

Plan A
 Artifact Handlers: Bamboo remote handler
Plan B
 Artifact Handlers: Amazon S3

Plan B uses Plan A artifacts for a build.
But like a this case both plans do not use same location, the build task fails.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set Plan A Artifact Handlers to Bamboo remote handler
# Set Plan B Artifact Handlers to Amazon S3
# Perform build

h3. Expected Results
Succeeded the build.

h3. Actual Results
Fail the build.
fields.summary: Artifacts sharing does not work with using Amazon S3 and Remote handler

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The greatest load by far that CI systems put on SCM systems is inefficiently configured polling for changes. As an admin, I want to know the load my plan configurations are putting on my source control management system(s) so I can identify inefficient configuration and correct it.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a UI section that surfaces information about which plans are configured to poll for changes, and at what frequency. This should also show the repositories that are linked to that build plan. Optionally this could also include other SCM stats, such as average/daily fetches / clones, whether shallow clones are enabled, etc; and should show an overall picture of the activity of the instance (e.g. "Your Bamboo server is polling various SCM systems for changes a total of 1,000,000 times per day")

This information should also be included in support zips, to enable Atlassian Support to analyse this info.

h3. Workaround
Various manual database queries can be run to gather some of this information,
